Literature Review: The past four decades have witnessed an unprecedented accumulation of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) of youth psychotherapies, with over 600 interventions published to date. Meta-analyses have played a pivotal role in synthesizing these findings, providing insights into the efficacy of various psychotherapies for youth mental health issues. This literature review aims to summarize the key findings from these meta-analyses, highlighting the limitations and implications of the research synthesis. The review will focus on the following themes: (a) the effectiveness of youth psychotherapies for anxiety and depression, (b) the benefits of single-session interventions, remote delivery, and low- and middle-income country settings, (c) the impact of societal sexism and racism on treatment outcomes, and (d) the stagnation of average treatment benefit across decades of research. The review will also discuss the opportunities for future research, including the integration of meta-analysis into policy and practice, and the identification of mechanisms of change to inform personalization of treatment.
